avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is considerable above 2000 m and low below. Slab avalanches can be triggered above 2000 m in some places by low additional loads and can reach medium size. Both fresh and older drift snowpacks as well as the weakly built-up old snowpack can be disturbed; fractures can also tear through into deeper weak layers. The avalanche prone locations generally increase rapidly from the tree line upwards. Drift snow areas and the transition from little to more snow should be consistently avoided. Whumpfing collapsing sounds when stepping on the snowpack can indicate danger.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Prone to triggering on weak old snowpack

snowpackStructure.comment: On a locally very varied snow surface, there is partly soft new fallen snow, which is overlaid by fresh, prone to triggering drift snow packs during the daytime changes. In general, there are often areas with little snow next to considerable snowdrift accumulations. The older snowdrift accumulations have been transformed in places to build up and are soft, in places hard as a board. The old snowpack consists of crusts with faceted crystals in between and deep rime. A break usually occurs around the uppermost crust. The total snow depth is well below average.

tendency.highlights: On Thursday, the foehn subsides, prone to triggering wind slabs are covered by fresh new fallen snow and are difficult to recognise.

weatherForecast.comment: On Wednesday, dense high cloud fields will predominate in foehn weather, with visibility often limited in the highest regions, especially on the main Alpine ridge. In the afternoon, unproductive snow showers are possible along the Hohe Tauern main ridge. In the Tauern, stormy southerly winds (peaks 80 to 100 km/h, a little more in the morning) will blow in the high alpine areas. The wind will generally weaken slightly in the afternoon. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -3 degrees, at 3000 metres around -4 degrees. Snowfall will spread during the night to Thursday.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is moderate above 2000 metres and low below. Slab avalanches can be triggered in a few places by low additional loads and can reach medium size if they tear through the old snowpack. Both fresh and older drift snowpacks as well as the weakly built-up old snowpack can be disturbed; fractures can also tear through into deeper weak layers. The avalanche prone locations increase rapidly from the tree line upwards. Drift snow areas and the transition from little to more snow should be consistently avoided. Whumpfing collapsing sounds when stepping on the snowpack can indicate danger.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Prone to triggering wind slab on weak old snowpack. Many stones.

snowpackStructure.comment: On a locally very varied snow surface, there is partly soft new fallen snow, which is overlaid by fresh snowdrift accumulations in the daytime changes in the aspects from west to north to east. In general, there are often areas with little snow next to considerable snowdrift accumulations. The older snowdrift accumulations have been transformed in places to build up and are soft, in places hard as a board. The old snowpack consists of crusts with faceted crystals in between and deep rime. A break usually occurs around the uppermost crust. The total snow depth is well below average.

tendency.highlights: On Thursday, the foehn subsides, the prone-to-triggering wind slab is covered by fresh new fallen snow and is difficult to recognise.

weatherForecast.comment: On Wednesday, dense high cloud fields will predominate in foehn weather, with visibility often limited in the highest regions, especially on the main Alpine ridge. In the afternoon, unproductive snow showers are possible along the Hohe Tauern main ridge. In the Tauern, stormy southerly winds (peaks 80 to 100 km/h, a little more in the morning) will blow in the high alpine areas. The wind will generally weaken slightly in the afternoon. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -3 degrees, at 3000 metres around -4 degrees. Snowfall will spread during the night to Thursday.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is moderate above 1900 metres and low below. In skiable terrain, small to medium-sized slab avalanches can be triggered in some places, especially in the northern and eastern sectors, by low additional loads. This is most likely in the transition from little to more snow and in the fresh, prone-to-triggering snowdrift accumulations. Avalanche prone locations increase rapidly from the tree line upwards.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind slab on weak persistent layer

snowpackStructure.comment: Around 10 cm of new fallen snow from Sunday lies on an otherwise very variable surface. These will be overlaid by prone-to-triggering snowdrift accumulations during the course of the day. In general, there are often areas with little snow next to snowdrift accumulations. In places, the older wind slab has been transformed and is soft, in places hard as a board. The old snowpack consists of crusts with faceted crystals in between and deep rime. Breakage usually occurs around the uppermost crust. The total snow depth is well below average.

tendency.highlights: Some new fallen snow with wind will slightly increase the avalanche danger on Thursday.

weatherForecast.comment: On Wednesday, denser high cloud fields will predominate with a foehn-like southerly flow and visibility will often be limited in the highest regions. Unproductive snow showers are possible along the Carinthian border in the afternoon. A strong southerly wind will blow in the summit regions. The wind will generally weaken slightly in the afternoon. Temperatures at 2000 metres will be around -3 degrees, at 3000 metres around -5 degrees. Snowfall will spread during the night to Thursday.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is low. In the northern and eastern exposures of the high altitudes, mostly small slab avalanches can still be triggered in a few places, often only with great additional load. Avalanche prone locations are in particular in very steep extreme terrain, where transitions from little to more snow as well as small, fresh pillows of wind drifted snow should be critically assessed. The risk of falling often outweighs the risk of burial, but be careful in the area of terrain traps!
avalancheActivity.highlights: Weak old snowpack with little snow.

snowpackStructure.comment: Little snow, south-facing many apere surfaces, broad ridge and ridges often completely blown off. The snow surface is variable. The old snowpack is weak, with faceted crystals between crusts.

tendency.highlights: No significant change in avalanche danger.

weatherForecast.comment: On Wednesday, the sky will often be covered with medium and high clouds. Visibility should be mostly unrestricted. Mostly it will remain free of precipitation or it will snow unproductively and intermittently. Moderate to brisk winds from south to east (peaks up to 70 km/h). Temperatures will be +2 degrees at 2000 metres and -4 degrees at 3000 metres.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche risk is low. The risk of stones and slipping on icy surfaces is higher than the risk of burial.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Hardly any snow and low avalanche danger.

snowpackStructure.comment: Little snow, lots of patches of ice. The hard to icy snow surface in the morning softens on the sunny slopes during the day. Edgy persistent weak layer weakens the snow base, fundament if present.

tendency.highlights: No significant change in avalanche danger.

weatherForecast.comment: On Wednesday, the sky will often be covered with medium and high clouds. Visibility should be mostly unrestricted and it will remain dry. Moderate to brisk winds from south to east (peaks up to 70 km/h). Temperatures at 2000 metres will be +2 degrees.

ALBINA.generalHeadline: Caution: Prone to triggering wind slab on weak persistent weak layer!
